citation.article-title: Methylarcula marina gen. nov., sp. nov. and Methylarcula terricola sp. nov.: novel aerobic, moderately halophilic, facultatively methylotrophic bacteria from coastal saline environments.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Methylarcula terricola sp. nov.
Methylarcula terricola (ter.ri'co.la. Gr. adj. terricola of the soil)
Has all the characteristics which define the genus.
Additionally, it has the following characteristics.
Colonies on methylamine-agar medium (4-5 d) are white, 2 mm in diameter.
Able to grow at 10-40 °C, pH 5.5-10.0 and 0.05-14% NaCl.
Optimal conditions for growth are 29-32 °C, pH 7.5-8.5 and 3-6% NaCl.
Utilizable carbon sources are mono- and dimethylamine, fructose, glucose, maltose, lactose, mannose, ribose, trehalose, galactose, xylose, sucrose, succinate, pyruvate, acetate.
Methylamine is oxidized to formaldehyde by the N-MG pathway enzymes: γ-GMA synthetase}lyase and N-MG synthase/lyase.
Level of DNA-DNA hybridization with the type species Methylarcula marina is around 25-30% (membrane method).
The type strain Methylarcula terricola h37T was isolated from coastal salty soil of the Black Sea (Crimea) and is deposited in the Russian Collection of Microorganisms as VKM B-2160T.
